Rethinking the Representation in Federated Unsupervised Learning with Non-IID Data

Xinting Liao1, Weiming Liu1, Chaochao Chen1, Pengyang Zhou1, Fengyuan Yu1, Huabin Zhu1,
Binhui Yao1, 2, Tao Wang2, Xiaolin Zheng1, Yanchao Tan3
1Zhejiang University, 2Midea Group, 3Fuzhou University
{xintingliao, 21831010, zjuccc, zhoupy, fengyuanyu, zhb2000, xlzheng}@zju.edu.cn,
tony.yao@midea.com, tao.wang.seu@gmail.com, yctan@fzu.edu.cn
Chaochao Chen is the corresponding author.
Abstract

Federated learning achieves effective performance in modeling decentralized data. In practice, client data are not well-labeled, which makes it potential for federated unsupervised learning (FUSL) with non-IID data. However, the performance of existing FUSLÂ methods suffers from insufficient representations, i.e., (1) representation collapse entanglement among local and global models, and (2) inconsistent representation spaces among local models. The former indicates that representation collapse in local model will subsequently impact the global model and other local models. The latter means that clients model data representation with inconsistent parameters due to the deficiency of supervision signals. In this work, we propose FedU2superscriptU2\text{U}^{2}Â which enhances generating uniform and unified representation in FUSLÂ with non-IID data. Specifically, FedU2superscriptU2\text{U}^{2}Â consists of flexible uniform regularizer (FUR) and efficient unified aggregator (EUA). FURÂ in each client avoids representation collapse via dispersing samples uniformly, and EUAÂ in server promotes unified representation by constraining consistent client model updating. To extensively validate the performance of FedU2superscriptU2\text{U}^{2}, we conduct both cross-device and cross-silo evaluation experiments on two benchmark datasets, i.e., CIFAR10 and CIFAR100.

1 Introduction

To meet the demands of privacy regulation, federated learning (FL)Â [31] is boosting to model decentralized data in both academia and industry. This is because FL enables the collaboration of clients with decentralized data, aiming to develop a high-performing global model without the need for data transfer. However, conventional FL work mostly assumes that client data is well-labeled, which is less practical in real-world applications. In this work, we consider the problem of federated unsupervised learning (FUSL) with non-IID dataÂ [43, 14], i.e., modeling unified representation among imbalanced, unlabeled, and decentralized data.

Utilizing existing centralized unsupervised methods cannot adapt to FUSLÂ which has non-IID dataÂ [44]. To mitigate it, one of the popular categories is to train self-supervised learning models, e.g., BYOLÂ [8], SimCLRÂ [3], and SimsiamÂ [5], in clients, and aggregate models via accounting extremely divergent modelÂ [44, 45], knowledge distillationÂ [9], and combining with clusteringÂ [30]. However, two coupling challenges of FUSL, i.e., CH1: Mitigating representation collapse entanglement, and CH2: Obtaining unified representation spaces, are not well considered.

The first challenge is that representation collapseÂ [13] in the client subsequently exacerbates the representation of global and other local models. Motivated by regularizing Frobenius norm of representation in centralized self-supervised modelsÂ [15, 21], FedDecorrÂ [36] tackles representation collapse with the global supervision signals in federated supervised learning. But directly applying these methods to FUSLÂ has three aspects of limitations. Firstly, it relies on large data batch sizeÂ [30] to capture reliable distribution statistics, e.g., representation variance. Besides, regularizing the norm of high-dimensional representations inevitably causes inactivated neurons and suppresses meaningful featuresÂ [18]. Moreover, clients cannot eliminate representation collapse entanglement by decorrelating representations for FUSLÂ problem, once clients represent data in different representation spaces.

The second challenge refers to optimizing inconsistent client model parameters toward discrepant parameter spaces, bringing less unified representations among local models. Most of the existing FUSLÂ methods aggregate participating models with the ratio of samples, i.e., FedAvgÂ [31]. This not only fails to tackle the client shift from global optimum to local optimum, but also brings sub-optimal resultsÂ [22, 33]. To mitigate this, FUSLÂ methods maintain consistency by (1) abandoning extremely divergent clients by thresholdÂ [45, 44], (2) obtaining global supervised signal via clustering client sub-clustersÂ [30, 6], and (3) scaling angular divergence among client models in a layer-wise wayÂ [33]. These methods either forget to adjust clients updated with inconsistent directions, or break down the performance coherence among different layers of the whole model, failing to capture unified representations.

To fill this gap, we propose a framework, i.e., FedU2superscriptU2\text{U}^{2}, to enhance Uniform and Unified representation in FUSLÂ with non-IID data. To tackle CH1, we initially devise a flexible uniform regularizer (FUR) to prevent the sample representation collapse with no regard to data distribution and client discrepancies. In each client, FURÂ minimizes unbalanced optimal transport divergence between client data and uniform random samples, i.e., samples from the same spherical Gaussian distribution among clients. Thus it not only flexibly disperses local data representations toward ideal uniform distribution, but also avoids the representation collapse entanglement among clients without leaking privacy. To mitigate CH 2, we propose efficient unified aggregator (EUA) to aggregate a global model that maintains model consistency among global optimization and different local optimizations. Specifically, EUAÂ formulates model aggregation as a multiple-objective optimization based on the model deviation change rates of clients. EUAÂ reduces computation by searching exact solutions in the dual formulation with alternating direction methods of multipliers. Compared with conventional aggregation methods, we equivalently maintain consistent model updating based on client model deviation change, enhancing unified representations.

Summarily, we aim to enhance the representation in FUSLÂ by mitigating representation collapse and unifying representation generalization. (1) We enhance uniform representation by approaching data samples to spherical Gaussian distribution, which mitigates representation collapse and its subsequent entangled impacts. (2) We enhance unified representation by constraining the consistent updating of different client models. (3) To reach the above goals, we propose FedU2superscriptU2\text{U}^{2}Â with FURÂ and EUA, which is agnostic and orthogonal for the backbone of self-supervised models. (4) In our empirical studies, we conduct experiments on two benchmark datasets and two evaluation settings, which extensively validate the performance of FedU2superscriptU2\text{U}^{2}.

2 Related Work

2.1 Federated Unsupervised Learning

To enhance FUSLÂ with non-IID dataÂ [24], there are two categories of efforts, i.e., (1) generating global supervised signals, and (2) enhancing unified representation. The former targets at generating global supervised signals via local-global clusteringÂ [6], and sharing data representation among clientsÂ [41, 43]. But these methods either suffer from randomness in obtaining global supervision[30], or take the risk of leaking privacyÂ [44]. The latter enhances unified representation by adapting existing unsupervised representation methods, and tackling non-IID modeling with divergence-aware model aggregationÂ [44, 45, 33, 17, 30]. Both FedUÂ [44] and FedEMAÂ [45] enhance the awareness of heterogeneity in federated self-supervised learning by divergence-aware predictor update rule, and adaptive global knowledge interpolation, respectively. However, this kind of work overlooks representation collapse in non-IID clients. OrchestraÂ [30] utilizes local-global clustering derived from K-FedÂ [6] to guide self-supervised learning. This brings additional cost for clustering and is fragile to random initialization. Moreover, FedXÂ [9] devises local relational loss to distill the invariance of data samples, and global relational loss to maintain client inconsistencies. Recently, L-DAWAÂ [33] corrects the FUSLÂ optimization trajectory by measuring and scaling angular divergence among client models in a layer-wise way. However, it is hard to guarantee that the newly aggregated global model is still compatible and performant as a consistent model. Differently, the proposed FedU2superscriptU2\text{U}^{2}Â enhances uniform and unified representation without the prior knowledge of unsupervised models, data distribution, and federated settings.

2.2 Representation Collapse

Representation collapseÂ [15, 21] means representation vectors are highly correlated and simply span a lower-dimensional subspace, which is widely studied in metric learningÂ [34], i.e., self-supervised learningÂ [15], and supervised federated learningÂ [36]. In federated supervised learning, FedDecorrÂ [36] finds the dimensional collapse entanglement among server and client models, and decorrelates representations via regularizing the Frobenius norm of batch samples. However, FedDecorr relies on large batch size and deactivates lots of neuron parameters, degrading performance once the scale of clients increasesÂ [18]. To avoid representation collapse entanglement in FUSL, the proposed FURÂ in FedU2superscriptU2\text{U}^{2}Â will regularize data representations to a uniform distribution that is the same among clients. In this way, decorrelating representation is not affected by the data sampling. Meanwhile, the data is uniformly dispersed into the same random distribution space, avoiding intriguing collapse impacts of client collaboration.

3 Method

3.1 Federated Unsupervised Learning Formulation

We introduce the FUSLÂ problem formulation and related assumptions in the following. Empirically, we assume a dataset decentralizes among Kğ¾K clients, i.e., ğ’Ÿ=âˆªkâˆˆ[K]ğ’Ÿkğ’Ÿsubscriptğ‘˜delimited-[]ğ¾subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘˜\mathcal{D}=\cup_{k\in[K]}\mathcal{D}_{k}. FUSLÂ can be formulated as a global objective that seeks a collaborative aggregation among clients, i.e.,

The common aggregation approach is to assign the ratio of sample amount in client kğ‘˜k as the weight ratio, e.g., FedAvgÂ [31]. Nevertheless, the client with a large amount of data will dominate in aggregating, deteriorating the optimization of other clients with inconsistent local optimumsÂ [33]. Due to privacy constraints, directly aligning client local optimums with representations is forbiddenÂ [44, 45]. Therefore, it is necessary to account for a multi-objective optimal combination, i.e., restraining the consistency between global and local model parameters.

3.2 FedU2superscriptU2\text{U}^{2}Â Overview

To address FUSLÂ with non-IID data, i.e., Eq.Â (1), we propose FedU2superscriptU2\text{U}^{2}, whose framework overview is depicted in Fig.Â 1. There are one server and Kğ¾K clients in FedU2superscriptU2\text{U}^{2}, which share the same self-supervised model, e.g., SimsiamÂ [5], SimCLRÂ [3], and BYOLÂ [8]. Additionally, FedU2superscriptU2\text{U}^{2}Â contains extra flexible uniform regularizer (FUR) module, which mitigates representation collapse without requiring prior knowledge for FUSL. We introduce the unsupervised local modeling at each client kğ‘˜k, and then illustrate the communication between clients and server. For a batch of image data ğ‘¿ğ‘¿\bm{X} at client kğ‘˜k, we augment them with two transformations, i.e., ğ‘¿v=Tvâ€‹(ğ‘¿)superscriptğ‘¿ğ‘£superscriptğ‘‡ğ‘£ğ‘¿\bm{X}^{v}=T^{v}(\bm{X}) for Tvâˆ¼ğ’¯similar-tosuperscriptğ‘‡ğ‘£ğ’¯T^{v}\sim\mathcal{T} with ğ’¯ğ’¯\mathcal{T} denoting transformation set and vâˆˆ{1,2}ğ‘£12v\in\{1,2\}. And feature extractor represents two views of augmented data with dğ‘‘d-dimensional l2âˆ’limit-fromsubscriptğ‘™2l_{2}-normalized representations, i.e., ğ’v=â„±ğœ½kâ€‹(ğ‘¿v)superscriptğ’ğ‘£subscriptâ„±subscriptğœ½ğ‘˜superscriptğ‘¿ğ‘£\bm{Z}^{v}=\mathcal{F}_{\bm{\theta}_{k}}(\bm{X}^{v}). Then for each view of sample representations, we maximize its representation space via approximating uniform Gaussian distribution in FUR. Meanwhile, we align two views of feature representations by predictor module (if available) and alignment module.

In one communication round, every participating client kğ‘˜k uploads its model parameters ğœ½ksubscriptğœ½ğ‘˜\bm{\theta}_{k} to server. Next, server with efficient unified aggregator (EUA) module, first formulates the client model aggregation as a multi-objective optimization based on different client model deviation change rates, and searches for a balanced model combination. Server further restrains client parameters in a consistent space, which not only enhances the consistency between global optimum and local optimums, but also captures unified representation for data of the same class but different clients. This communication between server and clients iterates until the performance of FedU2superscriptU2\text{U}^{2}Â converges.

3.3 FURÂ for Mitigating Representation Collapse

Representation collapse is a long-standing issue due to its intriguing phenomenon, e.g., constant collapse and partial/full dimensional collapseÂ [15, 8]. In federated learning, representation collapse not only degrades the performance of local clients, but also intricately affects the representation of global and local modelsÂ [36]. Besides, lacking labels, clients represent data samples to the space around local optimums, where decorrelating sample representations of limited client data suppresses capturing useful featuresÂ [18].

Without ground truth labels, self-supervised learning not only keeps the invariance of the same sample with different augmentations, but also expands the uniformity of different representations to avoid representation collapseÂ [40]. Given a batch of BğµB representations, i.e., ğ’B1={ğ’›i1}iâˆˆ[B]superscriptsubscriptğ’ğµ1subscriptsuperscriptsubscriptğ’›ğ‘–1ğ‘–delimited-[]ğµ\bm{Z}_{B}^{1}=\{\bm{z}_{i}^{1}\}_{i\in[B]} and ğ’B2={ğ’›i2}iâˆˆ[B]superscriptsubscriptğ’ğµ2subscriptsuperscriptsubscriptğ’›ğ‘–2ğ‘–delimited-[]ğµ\bm{Z}_{B}^{2}=\{\bm{z}_{i}^{2}\}_{i\in[B]}, we train the self-supervised model by minimizing the total objective as below:

The crucial of mitigating representation collapse is to enhance the representation uniformityÂ [40]. To relieve reliance on prior knowledge of client data, we regularize local sample representations to a random distribution with high entropy. Specifically, we select samples following the spherical Gaussian distribution, i.e., ğ’”âˆ¼ğ’©(0,1),s.t.,âˆ¥ğ’”âˆ¥=1\bm{s}\sim\mathcal{N}(0,1),s.t.,\|\bm{s}\|=1, as the prior. In this way, mitigating representation collapse in FUSLÂ not only avoids leaking privacy, but also disentangles the collapse impacts among clients. Then FURÂ regularizes the divergence between the data representations ğ’Bvsuperscriptsubscriptğ’ğµğ‘£\bm{Z}_{B}^{v} and a set of random samples following spherical Gaussian distribution ğ‘ºB={ğ’”i}iâˆˆ[B]subscriptğ‘ºğµsubscriptsubscriptğ’”ğ‘–ğ‘–delimited-[]ğµ{\bm{S}_{B}=\{\bm{s}_{i}\}_{i\in[B]}}:

Thus the uniform term â„“usubscriptâ„“ğ‘¢\ell_{u} disperses uniformly to avoid representation collapse without repulsing in instance-based contrastive learning.

Since the client data is non-IID, it will break the class separation when strictively constraining sample representation to approach random instancesÂ [39]. A more flexible method is to match data samples and random Gaussian samples with arbitrary or proportional masses, i.e., leaving the sampling coupling with lower uncertainties unmatched. And unbalanced Optimal Transport (UOT)Â [1, 35] is one of the effective resolutions. UOT computes the transport mappingÂ [26, 29, 28] between two sample masses of different distributions under the soft marginal constraints, e.g., l2âˆ’limit-fromsubscriptğ‘™2l_{2}-normalization between the predicted margin and the ground truth margin. FURÂ minimizes UOT divergence to regularize data samples approaching the spherical Gaussian distribution. Note that the spherical Gaussian distribution maximizes its entropy and distributes its samples uniformly. The mapped data representations enjoy the above nice properties of spherical Gaussian distribution and further mitigate the representation collapse entanglement.

3.4 EUAÂ for Generalizing Unified Representation

Due to non-IID client data, clients optimize to their local optimums with inconsistent model parameters, causing inconsistent even conflicting model deviations from server to clients. Without the guidance of supervision signals, i.e., data labels, this problem further exacerbates in representing data of the same class but different clients, towards inconsistent spaces. Thus it is vital to constrain the consistency among client models in parameter spaces, which further guarantees unified representations.

In round tğ‘¡t, the impact of global aggregation on kğ‘˜k-th local optimization can be measured with the model deviation change rate, i.e.,

ckâ€‹(Î·,ğ’…t)=ukâ€‹(ğœ½gt)âˆ’ukâ€‹(ğœ½gt+1)ukâ€‹(ğœ½gt)â‰ˆÎ·gâ€‹âˆ‡logâ¡ukâ€‹(ğœ½gt)â€‹ğ’…t,subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜ğœ‚superscriptğ’…ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¢ğ‘˜subscriptsuperscriptğœ½ğ‘¡ğ‘”subscriptğ‘¢ğ‘˜subscriptsuperscriptğœ½ğ‘¡1ğ‘”subscriptğ‘¢ğ‘˜subscriptsuperscriptğœ½ğ‘¡ğ‘”subscriptğœ‚ğ‘”âˆ‡subscriptğ‘¢ğ‘˜subscriptsuperscriptğœ½ğ‘¡ğ‘”superscriptğ’…ğ‘¡\displaystyle c_{k}\left(\eta,\bm{d}^{t}\right)=\frac{u_{k}\left(\bm{\theta}^{t}_{g}\right)-u_{k}\left(\bm{\theta}^{t+1}_{g}\right)}{{u}_{k}\left(\bm{\theta}^{t}_{g}\right)}\approx\eta_{g}\nabla\log{u}_{k}(\bm{\theta}^{t}_{g})\bm{d}^{t}, (7)

where ukâ€‹(ğœ½gt)=â€–ğœ½gtâˆ’ğœ½ktâ€–2subscriptğ‘¢ğ‘˜subscriptsuperscriptğœ½ğ‘¡ğ‘”superscriptnormsubscriptsuperscriptğœ½ğ‘¡ğ‘”subscriptsuperscriptğœ½ğ‘¡ğ‘˜2u_{k}(\bm{\theta}^{t}_{g})=\|\bm{\theta}^{t}_{g}-\bm{\theta}^{t}_{k}\|^{2} is the model deviation from server to client kğ‘˜kÂ [16, 12], and global model optimization is ğœ½gt+1=ğœ½gtâˆ’Î·â€‹ğ’…tsuperscriptsubscriptğœ½ğ‘”ğ‘¡1superscriptsubscriptğœ½ğ‘”ğ‘¡ğœ‚superscriptğ’…ğ‘¡\bm{\theta}_{g}^{t+1}=\bm{\theta}_{g}^{t}-\eta\bm{d}^{t} with updating direction ğ’…tsuperscriptğ’…ğ‘¡\bm{d}^{t} and step size Î·ğœ‚\eta. Overlooking inconsistent model deviations, global aggregated model inevitably gets close to a subset of clients while deviating from others. It corresponds that clients get close to the global model increase the model deviation change rate, and clients away decrease itÂ [12, 32]. Motivated by this, we seek the clients with the worst model deviation change rate, and correct the global optimization with a direction maximizing the overall worst model deviation change rate. This can be formulated as a multi-objective optimization, which benefits for mitigating the inconsistencies and conflicts among clientsÂ [12, 42], i.e.,

where ğ’‘ğ’‘\bm{p} denotes the weights for different clients.

Theorem 1 (Optimization consistency of model deviations).

After the convergence of global and local optimization, EUAÂ balances the model deviation change rate among all clients, making the global aggregation improves all model equivalently. Therefore, all models optimize towards a consistent parameter spaces, obtaining unified representation.

3.5 Overall Algorithm and Convergence Analysis

We describe the overall algorithm of FedU2superscriptU2\text{U}^{2}Â in Algo.Â 1. In detail, the server collaborates with clients in steps 1:10. After collecting participating client models in step 8, server uses EUAÂ to reach a consistent model updating and obtain unified representations. The client executes self-supervised modeling in steps 11:21, where FURÂ enhances uniform representations to avoid collapse entanglement in step 17.

Convergence Analysis. In the following, we take four mild assumptionsÂ [23], and provide the generalization bounds of model divergence and overall convergence error.

4 Experiments

4.1 Experimental Setups

Datasets.We adopt two benchmark datasets, i.e., CIFAR10 and CIFAR100Â [20], to evaluate FedU2superscriptU2\text{U}^{2}. Both datasets have 50,000 training samples and 10,000 test samples, but differ in the number of classes. Following FedEMAÂ [45], we simulate non-IID data distribution in Kğ¾K clients by assuming class priors follow the Dirichlet distribution parameterized with non-IID degree, i.e., Î±ğ›¼\alphaÂ [11]. The smaller Î±ğ›¼\alpha simulates the more non-IID federated setting. We conduct extensive experiments in both cross-silo (K=10ğ¾10K=10) and cross-device (K=100ğ¾100K=100) settings to validate performance generalization.

Comparison Methods. We compare FedU2superscriptU2\text{U}^{2}Â with three categories of approaches , i.e., (1) combining the existing centralized self-supervised model with FedAvgÂ [31]: FedSimsiam, FedSimCLR, and FedBYOL, (2) the state-of-the-art FUSLÂ methods: FedUÂ [44], FedEMAÂ [45], FedXÂ [9], OrchestraÂ [30], and L-DAWAÂ [33], and (3) adapting existing federated supervised learning models solving representation collapse to FUSL: FedDecorrÂ [36]. Firstly, we evaluate the representation performance of the above methods with their best-performing models on both cross-silo and cross-device settings on CIFAR10 and CIFAR100 (Î±=0.1ğ›¼0.1\alpha=0.1). Secondly, we study the effectiveness of different methods with the same model, i.e., BYOL, for different non-IID degreesÂ [25], i.e., Î±={0.1,0.5,5}ğ›¼0.10.55\alpha=\{0.1,0.5,5\}. We evaluate the pre-trained encoder model via the accuracy of KNNÂ [4], standard linear probingÂ [2], and semi-supervised methods (i.e., fine-tuning 1% and 10% labeled data). All of the above metrics illustrate better performance when the values are higher.

Implemental Details. We conduct image augmentation for SimCLR, BYOL, and SimSiam, following their original papers. We adopt ResNet18Â [10] as an encoder module, choose Projector/Predictor architectures like original papers, and optimize each model 5 local epochs per communication round until converging. We set all datasets with batch size as 128 and embedding dimension as 512. To obtain fair comparisons, we conduct every experiment for each method with its best hyper-parameters, and report the average result of 3 repetitions. We choose AdamÂ [19] as the optimizer for each local model, and SGDÂ [37] for updating the global model. We set the uniformity effect Î»U=0.1subscriptğœ†ğ‘ˆ0.1\lambda_{U}=0.1, the soft margin constraints Ï„a=Ï„b=0.8subscriptğœğ‘subscriptğœğ‘0.8\tau_{a}=\tau_{b}=0.8, the coefficient of constraints Ï•=0.1italic-Ï•0.1\phi=0.1, and the coefficient in ADMM Ï=1ğœŒ1\rho=1.

4.2 Experimental Results

Representation Performance Comparison. Firstly, we follow the existing FUSLÂ methodsÂ [45, 30, 33], to evaluate the performance of pre-trained models learned in Tab.Â 1. We group the state-of-the-art methods in terms of their best-performing models, i.e., Simsiam, SimCLR, and BYOL. For the first group, we can observe that FedDecorr performs the worst, especially on CIFAR100 cross-device task. It indicates that directly avoiding collapse via decorrelating a batch of data representations is unsuitable for FUSLÂ with limited data and severely heterogeneous data distribution. In terms of the second group, compared with FedX, L-DAWA performs better on CIFAR100, while is less competitive on CIFAR10. We can conclude that: (1) L-DAWA can better control model divergence when clients have inconsistent optimums, and (2) L-DAWA fails to obtain discriminative representations since it takes no action to representation collapse. On mentioned the third group, Orchestra captures global supervision signals to guide data representation, whose effectiveness suffers from randomness. In general, directly combining existing self-supervised model with FedAvg cannot tackle FUSLÂ with non-IID data well. Cross-device simulation on CIFAR100 is so challenging that some existing methods fail dramatically. Moreover, FedU2superscriptU2\text{U}^{2}Â is agnostic to self-supervised model and performs better than existing work, which validates the superiority of enhancing uniform and unified representations.

Effect of Heterogeneity on Generalization. Next, we report the KNN-accuracy of cross-silo methods on CIAFR10 and CIFAR100 in Tab.Â 2, for validating the performance generalization. We choose the same model, i.e., BYOL, to be comparable among all FUSLÂ methods. We can discover that: (1) Most FUSLÂ methods increase their performance when the non-IID degree Î±ğ›¼\alpha increases, and the performance variances among different methods increase with the decreasing of Î±ğ›¼\alpha. (2) FedEMA-BYOL is not sensitive to the non-IID degrees, while Orchestra behaves on opposite. This states that capturing global supervision signals to guide local representation suffers from clustering randomness. (3) FedU2superscriptU2\text{U}^{2}Â performs the best among all tasks, even in Î±=0.1ğ›¼0.1\alpha=0.1, illustrating its performance generalization.

Ablation Studies. In Tab.Â 2, we also consider two variants of FedU2superscriptU2\text{U}^{2}: (1) FedU2superscriptU2\text{U}^{2}Â removes FUR, i.e., FedU2superscriptU2\text{U}^{2}-FUR, (2) FedU2superscriptU2\text{U}^{2}Â removes EUA, i.e., FedU2superscriptU2\text{U}^{2}-EUA, to study the effect of each module. From Tab.Â 2, we can see that either applying FURÂ or EUAÂ can enhance representations, since they have better performance than the existing FUSLÂ methods. Compared with FedU2superscriptU2\text{U}^{2}, FedU2superscriptU2\text{U}^{2}-FURÂ and FedU2superscriptU2\text{U}^{2}-EUAÂ drop KNN accuracy slightly, validating the effectiveness of tackle two challenges, i.e., representation collapse entanglement, and generating unified representations. FedU2superscriptU2\text{U}^{2}-FURÂ performs better than FedU2superscriptU2\text{U}^{2}-EUAÂ when Î±=0.1ğ›¼0.1\alpha=0.1, while gets worse when Î±=5ğ›¼5\alpha=5.

4.3 Representation Visualization

Analysis of Representation Collapse Entanglement. To study the representation collapse entanglement caused by non-IID data, we capture the representation covariance matrices of Nğ‘N test data points on CIFAR10 from both the global and local BYOL models of FUSLÂ methods, i.e., FedDecorr, L-DAWA, FedBYOL, and FedU2superscriptU2\text{U}^{2}. And we utilize the singular value decomposition on each of the representation covariance matrices, and visualize the top-100 singular values in Fig.Â 3. Both L-DAWA and FedBYOL suffer from severe representation collapse, because they have less singular values beyond 0 than FedDecorr and FedU2superscriptU2\text{U}^{2}. The representation collapses in global model and local model are consistent, proving that collapse impacts are entangled intricately. Compared with the singular values decomposed from the covariance matrix of Gaussian random samples, the singular values of FedDecorr and FedU2superscriptU2\text{U}^{2}are not similar. Because a fully uniform distribution breaks down the alignment effect and deteriorates clustering. Furthermore, in Fig.Â 4, we visualize the representation collapse on 3-D spherical space, where the existing FUSLÂ methods leave evident blank space and suffer from collapse entanglements.

Analysis of Unified Representation. We also use t-SNEÂ [38] to picture the 2-D representation of both global (circle) and local (cross) BYOL models in Fig.Â 5. There are three interesting conclusions: Firstly, FedU2superscriptU2\text{U}^{2}Â has clearer cluster boundary than FedDecorr, validating that directly decomposing the Frobenius norm of representations deteriorates generalization. Secondly, compared with FeBYOL, the global and local representations of L-DAWA are looser, implying its ineffectiveness in controlling conflicting model deviations. Lastly, with the effect of EUA, FedU2superscriptU2\text{U}^{2}Â achieves tighter distribution consistency between global and local representations, as well as more clear cluster bound.

Hyper-parameters sensitivity. We consider the sensitivity of highly relevant hyper-parameters, i.e., the effect of uniformity term Î»U={0,0.01,0.05,0.1,0.2,0.5}subscriptğœ†ğ‘ˆ00.010.050.10.20.5\lambda_{U}=\{0,0.01,0.05,0.1,0.2,0.5\} on Cifar10 Cross-silo (Î±=0.1)\alpha=0.1), in Fig.Â 6. We set Î»U=0.1subscriptğœ†ğ‘ˆ0.1\lambda_{U}=0.1 in experiments since it reaches the highest performance. And we leave the number of clients K={5,10,20,50,100}ğ¾5102050100K=\{5,10,20,50,100\} and the local epochs E={5,10,20,50}ğ¸5102050E=\{5,10,20,50\} in Appendix B.

5 Conclusion

In this work, we propose a FUSLÂ framework, i.e., FedU2superscriptU2\text{U}^{2}, to enhance Uniform and Unified representation. FedU2superscriptU2\text{U}^{2}Â consists of flexible uniform regularizer (FUR) and efficient unified aggregator (EUA). FURÂ encourages data representations to uniformly distribute in a spherical Gaussian space, mitigating representation collapse and its subsequent entangled impacts. EUAÂ further constrains the consistent optimization improvements among different client models, which is good for unified representation. In our empirical studies, we set both cross-silo and cross-device settings, and conduct experiments on CIFAR10 and CIFAR100 datasets, which extensively validate the superiority of FedU2superscriptU2\text{U}^{2}.

A.3 Convergence Error Bound

Definition 1 (Heterogeneity QuantificationÂ [23]).

Let Fâˆ—superscriptğ¹F^{*} and Fkâˆ—superscriptsubscriptğ¹ğ‘˜F_{k}^{*} be the minimum values of Fğ¹F and Fksubscriptğ¹ğ‘˜F_{k}, respectively. We use the term Î“=Fâˆ—âˆ’âˆ‘k=1Npkâ€‹Fkâˆ—Î“superscriptğ¹superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ‘subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğ¹ğ‘˜\Gamma=F^{*}-\sum_{k=1}^{N}p_{k}F_{k}^{*} for quantifying the degree of non-IID. If the data are IID, then Î“Î“\Gamma obviously goes to zero as the number of samples grows. Appendix B Experimental Supplementary

B.1 Hyper-parameter Sensitivity Analysis

In the following, we study the sensitivity of remaining highly relevant hyper-parameters, i.e., the effect of client numbers and local epochs. Specifically, we compare FedU2superscriptU2\text{U}^{2}-SimCLR and its runner-up method, i.e., FedX-SimCLR, on CIFAR10 Î±=0.1ğ›¼0.1\alpha=0.1, by varying the local epochs E={5,10,20,50}ğ¸5102050E=\{5,10,20,50\} in Fig.Â 7 and the number of clients K={5,10,20,50,100}ğ¾5102050100K=\{5,10,20,50,100\} in Fig.Â 8. We train all models until converge to obtain fairly comparable results. As we can see: (1) With the increase of local epochs, each client of FedX-SimCLR obtains a better-performing model, while each client of FedU2superscriptU2\text{U}^{2}-SimCLR is insensitive. This states that FedU2superscriptU2\text{U}^{2}Â balances the client model deviation change rate in EUA, bringing the benefits of quick convergence. (2) The performance of all methods decreases when the number of clients increases, but FedU2superscriptU2\text{U}^{2}-SimCLRÂ consistently outperforms FedX-SimCLR. It validates that enhancing uniform and unified representations will make FUSLÂ methods more generalizable to the cases of various participants amounts.

B.2 Enlarged Figures in Visualization

In our main paper, we depict the top-k singular values of covariance matrix representations in Fig.Â (3), the corresponding 3-D representation in Fig.Â (4), and the distribution of data representation in Fig. (5) between global model and randomly sampled local models. The purpose of the above figures is to illustrate the representation enhancement of FedU2superscriptU2\text{U}^{2}. In Fig.Â 9-11, we enlarge these figures to explore the detailed comparisons. In terms of Fig.Â 11, FedU2superscriptU2\text{U}^{2}Â keeps the unified representation between global and local models as well as clearer decision boundary for each class.
